sections.title: Introduction to Biometric Authentication
sections.content: Biometric authentication uses unique physical or behavioral characteristics to verify identity. Unlike passwords or PINs, biometric traits are inherently tied to an individual and cannot be easily stolen or forgotten.
keyPoints: Biometrics measure unique physical or behavioral characteristics
Common biometric modalities: fingerprint, face, iris, voice
More secure than traditional password-based systems

sections.title: Cryptographic Hash Functions
sections.content: A cryptographic hash function is a mathematical algorithm that maps data of arbitrary size to a fixed-size output (hash value). Hash functions are deterministic, one-way, and collision-resistant.
keyPoints: Deterministic: Same input always produces same output
Collision-resistant: Hard to find two inputs with same hash
Avalanche effect: Small input change drastically changes output

example.observation: Single character change completely alters the hash

sections.title: Salt in Cryptography
sections.content: A salt is random data added to the input before hashing. Salts prevent rainbow table attacks and ensure that identical inputs produce different hashes when different salts are used.
keyPoints: Random, unique value generated for each user
Ensures unique hashes even for identical biometric data

example.observation: Same biometric + different salt = different hash

sections.title: Hashing Biometric Data
sections.content: Combining biometric authentication with cryptographic hashing creates a secure, irreversible representation of biometric data. This protects privacy and prevents biometric theft.
keyPoints: Raw biometric data is never stored
Only hash values are stored in database
Even database compromise doesn't reveal biometric data
Hash cannot be used to reconstruct original biometric

process.name: Feature Extraction
process.description: Extract unique features from biometric sample

process.name: Storage
process.description: Store hash and salt in database

sections.title: Enrollment Phase
sections.content: Enrollment is the initial registration process where a user's biometric data is captured, processed, and securely stored for future verification.
steps: Template + salt are hashed using SHA-256
Hash and salt are stored in secure database
User ID is linked to stored hash
securityConsiderations: Multiple samples may be captured for accuracy

sections.title: Verification Phase
sections.content: Verification is the authentication process where a new biometric sample is captured and compared against stored hash values to confirm identity.
steps: User presents biometric trait for verification
System retrieves stored salt for that user
New hash is compared with stored hash
Access granted or denied based on result

matchingThreshold.description: Similarity score required to accept match

errorTypes.description: Accepting an impostor as genuine user

sections.title: Security Advantages
sections.content: Biometric cryptography provides multiple layers of security that traditional authentication methods cannot match.

advantages.description: Raw biometric data never stored, eliminating primary attack vector
Hash cannot be reversed to obtain original biometric
Each person's biometric hash is unique
Cannot share or steal biometric traits like passwords
Prevents replay attacks with fake biometrics
Combines 'something you are' with cryptographic security

sections.title: WebAuthn API
sections.content: Web Authentication API (WebAuthn) is a web standard for secure, passwordless authentication using biometrics or security keys.
keyFeatures: Built into modern browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge)
Supports fingerprint, face, and hardware tokens
Resistant to phishing and credential theft
workflow: Server validates assertion and grants access

sections.title: Threats and Mitigations
sections.content: Understanding potential security threats and implementing appropriate countermeasures.

threats.description: Using fake biometric (photo, mask, replica fingerprint)
Attacker gains access to stored hashes
threats.mitigation: Hashing with salt prevents biometric reconstruction

sections.title: Real-World Applications
sections.content: Biometric cryptography is deployed across various industries and use cases.

glossary.biometric: A measurable physical or behavioral characteristic unique to an individual
glossary.hash: Fixed-size output of a cryptographic hash function
glossary.salt: Random data added to input before hashing
glossary.enrollment: Process of capturing and storing biometric template
glossary.verification: Process of comparing new biometric sample to stored template
glossary.FAR: False Acceptance Rate - probability of accepting impostor
glossary.FRR: False Rejection Rate - probability of rejecting genuine user
glossary.liveness: Detection mechanism to ensure biometric is from living person
glossary.template: Digital representation of extracted biometric features
